findings.title: UMP - Unusual Minting Process
findings.description: The contract utilizes a minting function that requires users to specify a unique token ID when minting a new NFT, which can lead to potential challenges and deter users from interacting with the contract due to added complexity and potential for errors.

findings.title: IRM - Incorrect Reward Mechanism
findings.description: The contract's pendingreward function calculates rewards incorrectly, leading to flawed calculations and potential loss of stakeholder trust.

findings.title: MUR - Missing Upline Reset
findings.description: The contract does not reset `nftdata.upline` during the `unstake` function, causing the upline address to remain unchanged indefinitely.

findings.title: MU - Modifiers Usage
findings.description: The contract is using repetitive statements on some methods to validate preconditions instead of using modifiers.

findings.title: TUU - Time Units Usage
findings.description: The contract is using arbitrary numbers to form time-related values, decreasing code readability and preventing compiler optimization.

findings.title: IDI - Immutable Declaration Improvement
findings.description: The contract declares state variables that their value is initialized once in the constructor and are not modified afterwards.

findings.title: L02 - State Variables could be Declared Constant
findings.description: State variables can be declared as constant using the constant keyword to ensure their values cannot be changed after being set, which decreases gas consumption.

findings.title: L04 - Conformance to Solidity Naming Conventions
findings.description: The Solidity style guide provides guidelines for writing clean and consistent Solidity code, improving readability and maintainability.

findings.title: L09 - Dead Code Elimination
findings.description: Dead code can make a contract more difficult to understand and maintain, and can also increase the size of the contract and the cost of deploying and interacting with it.

findings.title: L17 - Usage of Solidity Assembly
findings.description: Using assembly can be useful for optimizing code, but it can also be error-prone. It's important to carefully test and debug assembly code to ensure that it is correct and does not contain any errors.

findings.title: L19 - Stable Compiler Version
findings.description: The `^` symbol indicates that any version of Solidity that is compatible with the specified version can be used to compile the contract, which may lead to vulnerabilities and undiscovered bugs.

findings.title: L20 - Succeeded Transfer Check
findings.description: According to the ERC20 specification, the transfer methods should be checked if the result is successful. Otherwise, the contract may wrongly assume that the transfer has been established.
